document.title: Diocese of Kansas City - St. Joseph

BCDAD9DD72B04C5685A2A445D6472E3F.description: Identify and use artifacts (building structures, fossils, cultural art)

7572D46B215F4D969220673192644787.description: Identify and use library and media resources

F81F162C46F04F17B978362A2C427CC3.description: Identify, use and create primary and secondary sources (diaries, letters, pictures)

3BAA5E1D63204323BAE56CC2B536FC99.description: Identify, select and use visual, graphic and auditory aids (timelines and diagrams)

A1D648B034524685817309BC5A96B233.description: Knowledge of the use of tools of social science inquiry (such as surveys, statistics, maps and documents)

650B7BACD0094DF7802F8D6F699A2BEB.description: Understand the impact of missionaries on the growth of our nation (schools, hospitals, orphanages)

127C77925E2B4FFC8458E41CD505F4B3.description: Identify how various cultures exchange different, values, beliefs, and experiences.

98AC8F8CA2B547D986E52A3BED44AF33.description: Compare how people's needs have been met in different ways in different cultures at various times.

13E70F65D32046EDBF21A395A16459DF.description: Knowledge of relationships of the individual and groups to institutions and cultural traditions.

2C83633CD3A744B7B653032C29857CC7.description: Describe major factors that impact human populations.

8390502147C941B5A345718D71471BFC.description: Describe and use absolute location on political and physical maps using the following elements: alpha-numeric grids, title, compass rose, symbols, legend, scale.

27CF22DAAA9B43588F77B7C069521B9A.description: Name the states of each region of the United States.

E210F9D4C1214144B2E54BDC35EAD3FC.description: Locate the regions of the United States.

698B903B652B4F1AAADAC0887C39B38E.description: Locate physical and human features on a map, globe, illustrations or images.  Physical: (i.e., seven continents, world's oceans, river, lake, mountain range, coast) Human: (i.e., equator, Northern/Southern Hemispheres, Northern/Southern Poles)

5B6177C3BCFC448FA4EB9A73EAE8A888.description: Recognize physical and human features on a map or globe.  Physical: (i.e., ocean, continent, river, lake, mountain range, valley, volcano), Human: (i.e., equator, North and Southern Hemispheres, North and South Poles)

B4C76F77FDBB44139334F349AE3F0DD0.description: Construct maps using symbols to represent human and physical features.

9472DFAD80EF4ED582C0D1C237BA758B.description: Construct a map of a familiar place (e.g., home, neighborhood, Biblical or fictional place) that includes a title, compass rose, symbols, and legend.

AFDDAB5A68394EAE932180FF19C6BEE9.description: Knowledge of major elements of geographical study and analysis (such as location, place, movement, and regions) and their relationship to changes in society and the environment.

327C6A226B8C4AFCBCD40F2D7F295598.description: List how tax moneys are used, who benefits from tax-supported services and who pays for these services

F3F7D98E00534342A3FC73D31320DECC.description: Identify taxes that students experience, such as sales tax

F4FD111BC66242F1901CC128ED54F12D.description: Conduct a cost-benefit analysis incorporating the production of natural resources to the final project

979D879A6164462BB20074E3C290CD42.description: Identify and give examples of consumers and producers

271D527E9C27444FAAAEAC95FC10E3C3.description: Compare natural, capital and human resources.

34BF8A76DC944B5793E1A457DBBD1EDD.description: Define and explain the principles of goods and services, including: scarcity, investment/savings, supply/demand, charitable organizations, community service, tithing, and stewardship.

FC899F91AEB7492483959EE3E89FF1BE.description: Knowledge of economic concepts and principles.

06957BF569714042BDC532DD202209FD.description: Introduce the role of the Civil War as a catalyst for change.

590F507203C1498992811013ACB3C00D.description: Describe the contributions of people who have influenced and shaped the modern world (i.e. Martin Luther King, Jr., Susan B. Anthony, Mother Theresa, and Mahatma Ghandi).

53C4E7B2C4814502A0EC42378BE36FBB.description: Introduce Westward Expansion (e.g., Lewis and Clark, Sacagawea, pioneers).

1A3E6093F4F2412A9DE619D28375B7F4.description: Knowledge of continuity and change in the history of the United States.

87EA831AC9534AD5B3152C9229309257.description: Analyze peaceful resolution of disputes by courts or other legitimate authorities, such as parents, teachers, principals, etc.

69179F7C37194B8D9055219F985B6642.description: Introduce and define the functions of the three branches of government.

478552B8C9594A30B1FB98B8493584D5.description: Recognize there are different levels of government (local, state, and federal).

C0278E6154364C48A4CAA967917AE041.description: Knowledge of principles and processes of governance systems.

883782791E4A4DEB9E65BE6344A702E6.description: State the main purposes of the Declaration of Independence.

3AC6FF91941442308D05A0A64B316809.description: Discuss and explain responsibilities of citizens including respect for the rights of others, paying taxes, voting, working for social justice, volunteering, stewardship.

DEED8A0F20014B4992E02131864A37CE.description: Identify and describe the basic sequence of how laws are made: law is proposed, discussed, amended, voted on.

3624FD70AD4D44A785A5CE7695BF8C69.description: Explain why cities make laws and ordinances.

2884E48226CC4A2BB07879D8D20EFB8F.description: Identify reasons why cities make laws and ordinances.

7509E88213BF4869BFE92F048CCB96C9.description: Describe how people in the community and state work together to achieve common goals.

A986B537D3394B3695432683C03720B4.description: Knowledge of the principles expressed in documents shaping constitutional democracy in the United States.

32249FE36F2C4C89BB0ED54DFB96714D.description: Plan and carry out fair tests in which variables are controlled and failure points are considered to identify aspects of a model or prototype that can be improved.

61447B2843A34DB6BFFC83AA853F3A58.description: Generate and compare multiple possible solutions to a problem based on how well each is likely to meet the criteria and constraints of the problem.

4A5424B2B09D428AA02472912373A8AF.description: Create a simple design problem reflecting a need or a want that includes specified criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or cost.

04F2F109B4374B30B7FD1AB38D8EE7A8.description: Compare structures (e.g., wings vs. fins vs. legs; gills vs. lungs; feathers vs. hair vs. scales) that serve similar functions for animals belonging to different vertebrate classes.

B7712CDEE4784706A879A3D1BDE2849D.description: Compare structures of plants that serve similar functions in different species of plants.

2FBE80AD21B5467389DCFCD17209EBA5.description: Construct an argument that plants and animals have internal and external structures that function to support survival, growth, behavior, and reproduction.

7AD22D78241141CD8190AFC0061CF969.description: Apply knowledge of specialized structures and senses and infer how they help animals survive in their environment (e.g., antennae, body covering, teeth, beaks, whiskers, appendages.)

5612AE135E66404EAE7D0E2D481CE5B8.description: Use a model to describe that animals receive different types of information through their senses, process the information in their brain, and respond to the information in different ways.

ABD09010559B402A918ED021FACFB0C5.description: Identify specialized structures and senses and describe how they help animals survive in their environment (e.g., antennae, body covering, teeth, beaks, whiskers, appendages.)

EDB5F8FA20474354B24A6E0879CDE552.description: Evaluate specialized structures and describe how they help plants survive in their environment (e.g., root, cactus needles, thorns, winged seed, waxy leaves.)

D414BD9A202A4864A9F8A26206FF212C.description: Identify the major organs (roots, stems, flowers, leaves) and their functions in vascular plants (e.g., absorption of water and light energy, transport, reproduction.) (Do NOT assess the term vascular.)

5961A0C88AA74705A67017131CA21D20.description: Use evidence to construct an explanation for how the variations in characteristics among individuals of the same species may provide advantages in surviving, finding mates, and reproducing.

D19E2D0C4D1E420C93FBB5CE2D09B6EE.description: Identify and relate the similarities and differences among animal parents and their offspring or multiple offspring.

DF01DAA59E7F40D6870A9E5BD41BDC29.description: Identify and relate the similarities and differences between plants and their offspring (i.e., seedlings.)

6F9B5167B2E540F18551EA7F693505BB.description: Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence that plants and animals have traits inherited from parents and that variation of these traits exists in a group of similar organisms.

BB393EF86D384CD28C25869494B63245.description: Observe, identify and sequence life cycles (birth, growth, and development, reproduction and death) of animals (i.e., butterfly, frog, chicken, snake, dog.)

70F45457DE5E4548A00DEB4E5A75E0CC.description: Describe and sequence the stages in the life cycle (for a plant) of seed germination, growth and development, reproduction, and death (i.e., a flowering plant.)

9ECD9CCA5C6D4EDEAD1A112E95051211.description: Develop models to describe that organisms have unique and diverse life cycles but all have in common birth, growth, reproduction, and death.

E6DAC21F00B74B6D88DB3F40354BE27E.description: Use the Gospel recounting of Jesus' calming of the storm (Matthew, Mark, and Luke) to show God's connection to this essential standard.

3EC16610A6C14B9B8CE823109D1E52E2.description: Research different solutions to environmental hazards to reduce their negative impact.

CCC148F3971E4886A446335A9668D726.description: Make a claim about the merit of a design solution that reduces the impacts of a weather-related hazard.

DECADD9D61B34D0D804120074D68199F.description: Use the Gospel recounting of Jesus' calming of the storm (Matthew, Mark, and Luke) to show God's connection to this essential standard.

EE4BD69DE9744A4E84A771A09363542C.description: Collect and interpret weather data (i.e., temperature, wind speed and direction, precipitation, cloud type and cover.)

933D2DD0E0CA487B87477C12D6F144AA.description: Obtain and combine information to describe climates in different regions of the world.

009D06962BBF4757BC4062F690F6C114.description: Use the Gospel recounting of Jesus' calming of the storm (Matthew, Mark, and Luke) to show God's connection to this essential standard.

AB2763F65A224CB5BAEABD30FDAC5AC3.description: Generalize relationships between weather data (e.g., temperature and time of day, cloud cover and temperature, wind direction and temperature) collected over a period of time.

5FDA77123F2948E49DFF7DF1BBA72166.description: Identify and use appropriate tools (i.e., thermometer, anemometer, wind vane, rain gauge, satellite images, weather maps) to collect weather data ( i.e., temperature, wind speed and direction, precipitation, cloud type and cover.)

F85FF8AD105249ED8DB3FC505F2216F9.description: Represent data in tables and graphical displays to describe typical weather conditions expected during a particular season.

64F3DE03A29D4561B7BDEF8E490095D0.description: Use the Gospel recounting of Jesus' calming of the storm (Matthew, Mark, and Luke) to show God's connection to this essential standard.

1708367EFEFD4C0FB379B47D3966E09C.description: Identify locations that hold water as it passes through the water cycle (e.g., oceans, atmosphere, fresh surface water, snow, ice, and ground water.)

E5B014C96B6244E0951407816E66E43D.description: Investigate and record temperature data to show the effects of heat energy on changing the states of water.

6E14FB7282674E6491F24A2263B59594.description: Describe the relationship between heat energy from the sun, evaporation and condensation of water on Earth.

859403237D044EC5847397213D496CFE.description: Describe the processes of evaporation, condensation, and precipitation as they relate to the water cycle.

DD34E588DEEE4D228EDAD05E0C14F366.description: Illustrate that water changes state as it moves through the water cycle.

2249C14B0529482583587AFA28EB9070.description: Formulate a solution to an environmental problem that effects plants and animals.

F3EDB4D83F7D4615931FACB3E15B6923.description: Use evidence to support the explanation that traits can be influenced by the environment.

DA536F5BA66446818D3AC76C7C226A2B.description: Connect environmental changes to the survival or adaptations of plants and animals.

4F65B358349046FAA28BF03E6664FAC9.description: Critique examples where human activity has had a beneficial or harmful effect on other organisms (e.g., feeding birds, littering vs. picking up trash, hunting/conservation of species, paving/restoring green space.)

59A52C73BB764CF5B84FE5693E56192A.description: Identify internal cues (e.g., hunger) and external cues (e.g., changes in the environment) that cause organisms to behave in certain ways (e.g., hunting, migration, hibernation.)

932C20C2E6E8488EB1EBA467E374CF4F.description: Predict and investigate the growth of plants when growing conditions are altered (e.g., dark vs. light, water vs. no water.)

77EDA2F68E7446A2992496B185D49F66.description: Make a claim about the merit of a solution to a problem caused when the environment changes and the types of plants and animals that live there may change.

C887BAADBD0E4DBAB7F9AF1DA4E36E26.description: Predict and justify which plant or animal will be able to survive in a local environment based on its special structures or behaviors.

744B311C5AD6442882CD024C6F24D0A4.description: Identify and describe how different environments (i.e. pond, forest, prairie) support the life of different types of plants and animals.

35E78D7D14E84EF0AFF06539927BB461.description: Recognize, classify, and categorize the ways a specific organism may interact with other organisms or with the environment (e.g., pollination, shelter, seed dispersal, camouflage, migration, hibernation, defensive mechanism.)

2F5D8DD9E4DA4342A9DF6B18073C7E51.description: Distinguish between producers, consumers, and decomposers.

E5E2179124154DA98BCB12B42F5DA5C0.description: Construct a food chain with organisms labeled as predator/prey, herbivore/omnivore/carnivore, and producer/consumer/decomposer.

AEEB86233FB842E8BECBACF2CE6860DE.description: Classify organisms as herbivore, omnivore, or carnivore.

894BEB63198A4395BEE756E2815F9F1C.description: Identify the basic needs of most animals (i.e., air, water, food, shelter.)

7A2B6DA0BA554A41BA622A2AFB839506.description: Recall and describe the basic needs of most plants (i.e., air, water, light, nutrients, temperature.)

2BD3882D384E404F85FC44E2DD08B74E.description: Judge a particular habitat to prove that some organisms can survive well, some survive less well, and some cannot survive at all.

6C2214E7938A48CA98432E9F31E259C4.description: Label type, size, and distributions of fossil organisms.  Examples of fossils and environments could include marine fossils found on dry land, tropical plant fossils found in arctic areas, and fossils of extinct organisms.

CBD838E550C847D6A8E645192F042F43.description: Compare and contrast common fossils (i.e., trilobites, ferns, crinoids, gastropods, bivalves, fish, mastodons) to organisms present on Earth today.

3322CEE9C1E54BA08EF139D0785E7EB1.description: Observe and describe the physical properties of rocks (e.g., size, shape, color, presence of fossils.)

294380017C01450983ADE6B67D9ED147.description: Analyze and interpret data from fossils to provide evidence of the organisms and the environments in which they lived long ago.

02773283A053447A82010CF63B72BF89.description: Identify and support the ways a specific organism may interact with other organisms or with the environment (e.g., pollination, shelter, seed dispersal, camouflage, migration, hibernation, defensive mechanism.)

B9C9AD9CB6424DA2B3A11DDBF7E45D09.description: Construct an argument that some animals form groups that help members survive.

C86E54DC642847F8AC5B5DEE450A4BC1.description: Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table), and explain them using properties of operations.  (e.g., observe that 4 times a number is always even, and explain why 4 times a number can be decomposed into two equal addends).

7DF0692E7DBA4129BCF1BA679C5D4C81.description: Solve two-step word problems using the four operations.  Represent these problems using a letter standing for the unknown quantity.  Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies using rounding.

A99C0A69B0B844C9AB3C4789C1AF6A66.description: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.

213FE556C680412682702FA4A77EE90A.description: Fluently multiply and divide within 100.  By the end of grade 3, know from memory all products through 10 x 10.

55F2A5B4A08E4831B6ACF40561D58386.description: Identify, describe, and apply division and multiplication as inverse operations by interpreting division as an unknown factor problem.  (e.g., find 32 ÷ 8 by finding the number that makes 32 when multiplied by 8).

5FD68F3CE0A943BCAA66672EC51C3FB8.description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide. (Commutative, Associative, and Distributive Properties)

EEDAD5B515E2427FBFB6E57D15891A83.description: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.

91E2B6038D65404E9178473CBE57E511.description: Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating three whole numbers.  (e.g., determine the unknown number that makes the equation true in each of the equations 8 x ? = 48, 5 = ? ÷ 3, 6 x 6 = ?).

7741D08BA1074FD2AB43FBA497EC4C79.description: Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and measurement quantities.  (e.g., use drawings and equations with a symbol for an unknown number to represent the problem).

BE1B1BA3658C44098C0BD9650E0A0FAE.description: Interpret whole number quotients of whole number.  (e.g., describe a context in which a number of shares or a number of groups can be expressed as 56 ÷ 8).

1C6B8040F2A145A097FD05B2B238406E.description: Interpret products of whole numbers. (e.g., describe a context in which a total number of objects can be expressed as 5 x 7).

1FF7BE04E7B64DEEB69CDAF72831693F.description: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.

DCD2F1962CE0405C93688D5B6552566E.description: Compare two fractions with the same numerator or the same denominator by reasoning about their size.  Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole.  Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, <, and justify the conclusions. (e.g., by using a visual model).

D7B98925E8954094886FFB840F22D4B0.description: Express whole numbers as fractions, and recognize fractions that are equivalent to whole numbers.  For example, express 3 in the form of 3 = 3/1; recognize that 6/1 = 6; locate 4/4 and 1 at the same point of a number line diagram.

6DD7C753D3004BCB85902E880EC69FEE.description: Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions. (e.g., 1/2 = 2/4, 4/6 = 2/3.  Explain why the fractions are equivalent, e.g.., by using a visual fraction model).

4B3BEE082C1A42F49B0C44E56E399451.description: Identify two fractions as equivalent if they are the same size, or the same point on a number line.

BC5ECA1A3DD0417CBA4E19AFF923B9C5.description: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.

7B0D0B5ECEAF4F1B9DE8F111752F5567.description: Represent and interpret fractions on a number line with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8.

B8C9C785AF1A4749A495561C9B295BC0.description: Represent and interpret a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts; represent and interpret a fraction a/b as the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/b.

391A418C46CB46668A35640B0F5AEB99.description: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

9F72249204074EEBBB0A7F897FA5360F.description: Read and write numbers to 100,000 using base ten numerals, number names, and expanded form.

A147973E1761432DA7A09DCFDE2E9B25.description: Multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 (e.g., 9 x 80, 5 x 60) using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.

68695B5222874A9CA41117B2B2F4B683.description: Fluently add and subtract within 1000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.

CE9E246C76534A1DBC4D36054D79DF18.description: Use place value understanding to round whole numbers to the nearest 10 or 100.

40746EA4E716456F8CE78BBC14435F4A.description: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.

46441CCD5863425FAEFC991F72C98F04.description: Solve real world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.

A9E05E386BDC4BF8B2511C904E835906.description: Geometric measurement: recognize perimeter as an attribute of plane figures and distinguish between linear and area measures.

F2B701EDD04B4533B369312A68669DD4.description: Recognize area as additive.  Find areas of rectilinear figures by decomposing them into non-overlapping rectangles and adding the areas of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real world problems.

8FEBF2EE374B47E1B443A4B50C58165F.description: Use tiling to show in a concrete case that the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths a and b+c is the sum of a x b and a x c.  Use area models to represent the distributive property in mathematical reasoning.

40CA69D653264FA8AEE881ECB21893C2.description: Multiply whole-number side lengths to find areas of rectangles in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.

BB8C80EC98ED46F0A5EF83D9A26EE186.description: Find the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths by tiling it, and show that the area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths.

28332674E6B9487EB5A2BD042900A287.description: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.

E6097EAC220149DA86A1E377595C6DED.description: Measure areas by counting unit squares (square cm., square m., square in., square ft., and improvised units).

66E9DE6DC218418DBE2A678089565D76.description: A plane figure which can be covered without gaps or overlaps by n unit squares is said to have an area of n square units.

6423BB49368D4090936F0A36ECDA4A02.description: A square with side length 1 unit, called "a unit square," is said to have "one square unit" of area , and can be used to measure area.

BBE77A8E515A44A59034EA1438C06213.description: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.

9290903FE48D4E569F474BF76DD13B3E.description: Understand concepts of area, using multiplication and addition.

282E6F764DF440B3A699AF0931F0AC62.description: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch.  Show the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in appropriate units - whole numbers, halves, or quarters.

3A51BFFB857D4026994EF339273667E1.description: Draw a scaled picture graph and scaled bar graph to represent a data set with several categories.  Solve one- and two- step "how many more" and "how many less" problems using information represented in scaled bar graphs.  (e.g., draw a bar graph in which each square in the bar graph might represent five hosts).

52FFF91C303F4E068B4565A211556C9F.description: Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using standard units of grams (g), kilograms (kg), and liters (l).  Add, subtract, multiply, or divide to solve one-step word problems involving masses or volumes that are given in the same units.  (e.g., use drawings (such as a beaker with a measurement scale) to represent the problem).

1231CA51B2234B62B0D1E7F6BF010A35.description: Show and determine the value of coin and currency combinations up to $5.00, determine change from $5.00, and solve problems with money using addition and subtraction.

FC52F90E405047F58F6CC1B1D81EE640.description: Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes.  Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes. (e.g., represent the problem on a number line diagram).

02C5B15022EB4B6F80ECE8EE753EFEEF.description: Solve problems involving time and money.

FA3AAED1C9A64ACC9D38FC70E19613AA.description: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation of intervals of time, money, liquid volumes, and masses of objects.

9B6BD6E9F36949898732D06CED8D5AA8.description: Draw and analyze 2-dimensional shapes from several orientations, and examine them for congruency and symmetry.

2925BCB9BBC748B896CA9A6B10C5D2A7.description: Analyze, compare, and classify 2-dimensional shapes using sides and angles, and connect these ideas to the definitions of the shapes.

4FE959C720FD407DAFC35F29A2E21C2A.description: Identify, describe, and classify 3-dimensional shapes, specifically cube, sphere, prism, pyramid, cone, and cylinder.

CE867FB2965440E4B88FE30E15FF463C.description: Identify, classify and analyze shapes and their attributes.

6FDD6E2F7D304E7BA67793F6DC581070.description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, including reflection of faith, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting, or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.

9D4279CCACC348409C0E2962FCB27CD5.description: Recall information from experiences or gather information from print and digital sources; take brief notes on sources and sort evidence into provided categories.

816E39CF86C34EE58B6B1606B4305214.description: Conduct short research projects that build knowledge about a topic.

37128A09ABFD499D85D62F970F963049.description: With guidance and support from adults, use technology to produce and publish writing (using keyboarding skills) as well as to interact and collaborate with others.

57497998A85A43C691C56F0CEACEB604.description: With guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, and editing.

DAB1D11099284332825B4CED0372F3A8.description: With guidance and support from adults, produce writing in which the development and organization are appropriate to task and purpose. (Grade-specific expectations for writing types are defined in standards 1–3 above.)

43DF4645D7B943FA977C87C19DA4CF00.description: Write poems, descriptions, and stories in which  figurative language and the sounds of words (e.g., alliteration, onomatopoeia, rhyme) are key elements.

38BB32B928CA4921920D0EB6AFA1B19A.description: Use temporal words and phrases to signal event order.

2537844A98DB44E9B16D2558CDC68FD8.description: Use dialogue and description of actions, thoughts, and feelings to develop experiences and events or show the response of characters to situations.

E165569342B7402EBF283FDF414F35C8.description: Establish a situation, introduce a narrator and/or characters, organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally.

8C2DA78068B24E588E63AD49E8F79B35.description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.

5BAE8409314B4D3FA2EA5822049D6C8F.description: Provide a concluding statement or section.

4007D40ADA014667B1AAB2EABDD031B4.description: Use linking words and phrases (e.g., also, another, and, more, but) to connect ideas within categories of information.

573078D3A6F54B2B89BB6ED6EF2B5ED1.description: Develop the topic with facts, definitions, and details.

C5215037BE044D88895E3B779DFC67ED.description: Introduce a topic and group related information together; include illustrations when useful to comprehension.

210A48C61DDB4C828503887C67A1ACF3.description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.

1E9C54F327EA46579B10057E1C26B6D8.description: Provide a concluding statement or section.

BB267ADB61354FC8ACC5D0AAF1F484F0.description: Use linking words and phrases (e.g., because, therefore, since, for example) to connect opinion and reasons.

30188E592CC24B5CAFF718C62C1C5814.description: Provide reasons that support the opinion.

11AAF41ADADA40FA930A4DA3A65393D1.description: Introduce the topic or text, state an opinion, and create an organizational structure that lists reasons.

E6635F51CFDF4947B2D9A10AD209B865.description: Write opinion pieces on topics or texts, supporting a point of view with reasons, including religious topics and themes.

1FADF0A46B3C4BEF81CDB55C1CED3568.description: Speak in complete sentences when appropriate to task and situation in order to provide requested detail or clarification. (See grade 3 Language standards 1 and 3 on pages 36–37 for specific expectations.)

61F4AD6F0B1F452E9E4FBF32D394915F.description: Create engaging audio recordings of stories or poems that demonstrate fluid reading at an understandable pace; add visual displays when appropriate to emphasize or enhance certain facts or details.

4B1FFF56E8BF4C41BDE5A0EA4A144F6F.description: Report on a topic or text, tell a story, or recount an experience with appropriate facts and relevant, descriptive details, speaking clearly at an understandable pace.

440F0ACC93594D66BB460E617B19A1C3.description: Ask and answer questions about information from a speaker, offering appropriate elaboration and detail.

ED31B7BF36D040478F4AC87A48C557F0.description: Determine the main ideas and supporting details of a text read aloud or information presented in diverse media and formats, including visually, quantitatively, and orally (eg. Gospel reading, and other religious texts).

BE44CC05CA284CF382DA5BBA51CE2603.description: Explain their own ideas and understanding in light of the discussion.

CF57F4811343459892EC37447728F467.description: Ask questions to check understanding of information presented, stay on topic, and link their comments to the remarks of others.

00208CFB7ED74726B7BAB90D4EC1AAA4.description: Follow agreed-upon rules for discussions (e.g., gaining the floor in respectful ways, listening to others with care, speaking one at a time about the topics and texts under discussion).

A1869C1D6C9F4847851173240AE0DDA4.description: Come to discussions prepared, having read or studied required material; explicitly draw on that preparation and other information known about the topic to explore ideas under discussion.

112B3CE94A5743E5A07134178A6EEC70.description: Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 3 topics and texts, building on others’ ideas and expressing their own ideas clearly.

F468F708FEC248E8BCDD568375696B1E.description: Identify elements of poetry. (e.g., rhyme, rhythm, figurative language, alliteration, onomatopoeia)

0F56EC1D4FC04F4C9883A22AC886778D.description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend, including religious text and Scriptures.

8B893548203E4A04AF105EE8CF00EA14.description: Compare and contrast the theme, setting, and plot of stories written by the same author and about the same or similar characters (e.g., in books from a series).

824A9243B004443180C9DD5CBF8238C7.description: Identify elements of fiction. (e.g., characters, setting, plot, problem, solution)

4E29254C394A42A2B63197AA00D14D3F.description: Explain how specific aspects of a text’s illustrations contribute to what is conveyed by the words in a story (e.g., create mood, emphasize aspects of a character or setting).

624F413E168749378C0EE58D0305C59E.description: Explain the author’s purpose (eg. to persuade, to entertain, to inform) while using evidence directly from the text to support. )

4C0A46A0592742DF8A527569470863B2.description: Distinguish their own point of view from that of the narrator or those of the characters.

AC8AF1A71AE8422185467C1B86AF3EA2.description: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.

E276BF2B2B8F441DBCCB4591A95B24BE.description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.

E5EE363816A24555B86D0A058D3F194F.description: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, spirituality or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.

61B6C23F3C3B441AA4BE97636188FBA0.description: Identify characteristics commonly shared by folktales and fairy tales.

13F12DFE7F0E4306B25DF55EEF3A8D58.description: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, Saints, Sunday Gospels, prayers and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.

88C99231112B482CB3C159EEA81A0669.description: Use prior knowledge and content to make, revise, and confirm predictions.

225B0A89DF17448BA8F95EF74E87B3C4.description: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers and when drawing inferences from the text.

A8EF109EE10A4F3DA5A9B9645377C350.description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend informational texts, including Scripture and religious texts, history/social studies, science, and technical texts, at the high end of the grades 2–3 text complexity band independently and proficiently.

34C2EEF123C24F4CB563D04D04E7F26D.description: Compare and contrast the most important points and key details presented in two texts on the same topic.

B846FE2E3C994FE5A672D5CC34741A64.description: Describe the logical connection between particular sentences and paragraphs in a text (e.g., comparison, cause/effect, first/second/third in a sequence).

690C71EC6ED042538874111E43A31081.description: Use information gained from illustrations (e.g., maps, photographs) and the words in a text to demonstrate understanding of the text (e.g., where, when, why, and how key events occur).

FB26932980B64322BC3C0DA4593DA1EB.description: Explain the author’s purpose (eg. To persuade, to entertain, to inform) while using evidence directly from the text to support. *

6A4E1ADD43F542FEB39A2D5D769C9615.description: Distinguish their own point of view from that of the author of a text.

D2256836F02A4CF6BFAC5B78F6590AF3.description: Use text features and search tools (e.g., key words, sidebars, hyperlinks) to locate information relevant to a given topic.

B1861F0F8CA84B83AF33BA3E00935BA1.description: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.

87DB0604A59446999F1E08D12C2E47F2.description: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, including  timeline of Jesus' life, scientific ideas, Catholic identity or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.

A99114BD1CDF461594EA964E7F896577.description: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.

36C8AF590C1D4869AAB98A3DC67B7975.description: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.

E64A4ECDD9F14A7AB2C5960D4B724BAA.description: Use knowledge of conventions (eg. ?, !, commas, ‘, “”, graphics, hyphens) to read fluently at instructional or independent reading levels.

9CF9DF21599543158ADBB13A22DEEB25.description: Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, rereading as necessary.

593F70DFC38B414EBE4B4629F321AD9C.description: Read grade-level prose and poetry orally with accuracy, appropriate rate, and expression on successive readings.

29EB0A6CC0734978A8A68EEE2CE9E197.description: Read grade-level text with purpose and understanding, while adjusting reading rate to difficulty and type of text.

E401678CB9ED407F9F80A3C456AC23DB.description: Read with sufficient accuracy and fluency to support comprehension.

16D20ACAAD8F410999E6F50965FD87DA.description: Decode words with common Latin suffixes.

D022734D601049B8A8CB39F1507A2CFE.description: Identify and know the meaning of the most common prefixes and derivational suffixes

8AA494E503564379BBFE5AD233FE0219.description: Know and apply grade-level phonics and word analysis skills in decoding words.

64699D2C81FC434892BBC9BD57FA399B.description: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate conversational, general academic, and domain-specific words and phrases, including those that signal spatial and temporal relationships (e.g., After dinner that night we went looking for them).

532476D1BEDC4371B554ABCC09059F15.description: Use the relationship between particular words (e.g., synonyms, antonyms, homographs) to better understand each of the words.

6F6781BFB3B04C0C9FFFE08BD56C7681.description: Distinguish shades of meaning among related words that describe states of mind or degrees of certainty (e.g., knew, believed, suspected, heard, wondered).

063D78F051084084B6EF12AF01EAA413.description: Identify real-life connections between words and their use (e.g., describe people who are friendly or helpful).

FF9D54A580B24DDCA28902E608A84121.description: Distinguish between the literal and nonliteral meanings of words and phrases in context (e.g., take steps).

3F64A660531E4CACB9E2592D929B66A6.description: Demonstrate understanding of word relationships and nuances in word meanings.

67F4811983524171BA87504710CCCB3F.description: Use glossaries or beginning dictionaries, both print and digital, to determine or clarify the precise meaning of key words and phrases.

416C1C84B8CC4CF6A088536E22F8974B.description: Use a known root word as a clue to the meaning of an unknown word with the same root (e.g., company, companion).

39614D1891E2434793D7B72EF93FF846.description: Determine the meaning of the new word formed when a known affix is added to a known word (e.g., agreeable/disagreeable, comfortable/uncomfortable, care/careless, heat/preheat).

34E2E81ED844404B89AE44D4FFBDDD67.description: Use sentence-level context as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

80D14F5F8E5F4EEBB8D5F835C7F41981.description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning word and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

3C692565A6C1449EBA1EB28AF6CBE1AE.description: Recognize and observe differences between the conventions of spoken and written English.

B1DD24E960FD402D8AD601A7D60C7D4C.description: Choose words and phrases for effect.*

3F9F8F38DE7A4232A3D35FE9DE1245ED.description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

04CB42BB67E141C09D3A64B98E553E05.description: Consult reference materials, including beginning dictionaries, as needed to check and correct spellings.

53E75AB7A2AB4732831CE2A218C7EB9F.description: Use spelling patterns and generalizations (e.g., word families, position-based spellings, syllable patterns, ending rules, meaningful word parts) in writing words.

FF8128B2181B47EBB46166CFD147ED7E.description: Use conventional spelling for high-frequency and other studied words and for adding suffixes to base words (e.g., sitting, smiled, cries, happiness).

3A3362B57DE6484BB6F015D290B6232B.description: Use commas and quotation marks in dialogue.

376A4C4F36654B4FA6389B878342808A.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

B0F1A0D09C32465DADED066ED7F93E46.description: Write legibly by hand, using either printing or cursive handwriting.

0F8B9A81906F4B90A416FFC0B5EEC6C3.description: Produce simple, compound, and complex sentences.

89A713B8A38540C09C613ABB9D675432.description: Form and use comparative and superlative adjectives and adverbs, and choose between them depending on what is to be modified.

39ADB9C80C794F858DD9D46A2CAC4D60.description: Form and use the simple (e.g., I walked; I walk; I will walk) verb tenses.

984DAD5FDDAC4A1FBA75029975CE6643.description: Form and use regular and irregular verbs.

498FE8BA93A74126A15968E8F4028932.description: Form and use regular and irregular plural nouns.

BE83567CB43043CC85BD57E31BFB35B0.description: Explain the function of nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs in general and their functions in particular sentences.

AF0A5ED0B35749DD86E6EE99AAEC9B1E.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
